bioghist.p: Joseph Leidy (1823-1891) was one of the preeminent figures in the development of American science in the nineteenth century. He was a physician, naturalist, anatomist, and scientific illustrator. Following William Wagner's death in 1885, Leidy assumed the role of President of the Faculty of the Wagner Free Institute of Science, with special direction of the Biology Department. Leidy was Chairman of the Board of Curators at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia, and is a central figure in that institution's history. He also taught courses at the University of Pennsylvania and at Swarthmore College.

scopecontent.p: This is a miscellaneous collection of letters, newspaper clippings and reports. Of note are 17 letters (1887-1890) from Leidy to Joseph Willcox concerning the Institute's publications, collections, and general Institute business; news clippings concerning Leidy's illness and death; a manuscript titled "Fossil flora of Lagrange, Ala." (1866) by W. Spillman; and a manuscript titled "A list of plants collected in the Minta Mts., and near Fort Bridges, Wyoming Territory" by Leidy and revised by Thos. L. Porter (1872); as well as a report written by Leidy to the Trustees of the Wagner Free Institute of Science in 1890 regarding his trip to Europe to purchase specimens.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
